newsitem.title: ISRAEL: KFC opens restaurant in Gaza Strip.
newsitem.headline: KFC opens restaurant in Gaza Strip.

text.p: Palestinians locked in the Gaza Strip under an Israeli closure got their first tast of American fast food on Wednesday when Kentucky Fried Chicken opened a franchise in the self-ruled territory.
"I'm really glad that we have such fast food," customer Farid Ayyad told Reuters. "I used to go abroad and have meals in these restaurants and I'm glad we have it now in our country."
Zaki Ghalli, one of three Gazan businessmen who bought the franchise through KFC regional headquarters in Cairo, said the restaurant imported all ingredients save produce from Egypt.
"We even import the chicken," Ghalli told Reuters.

One Palestinian protester used the restaurant's grand opening to vent anger at the United States, which last month twice vetoed United Nations resolutions censuring Israel's construction of a Jewish settlement in Arab East Jerusalem.
"No to the American veto," read a sign posted by the protester on Gaza City's main Omar Mukhtar street.
Customers were unfazed: "There is a difference between politics and food," Ayyad said.
Ghalli said an Israeli closure of the Gaza Strip had delayed the franchise's grand opening.
"We were supposed to open last month but we had problems becasue of the closure. The Israelis do not allow food to cross easily," Ghalli said.

Israel periodically seals off its borders with the impoverished Strip for security reasons. A 1993 Israeli-PLO peace deal launched Palestinian self-rule in Gaza but left Israel with overall security control at border crossings.
A two-piece chicken meal with cole slaw, bun and french fries sells for 10 shekels ($3).
